items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 2:45am and 4:45am tomorrow early hours, Wednesday 23rd February. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.79mAODN at 3:45am, on Wednesday 23rd February, which is 0.66m above tide tables, wind Force 4, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Unsettled conditions are forecast for the next few days, however the current series of high spring tides has now reached its peak, and will fall away over the next few days. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 23rd February.

items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray caused by strong winds are expected on Tuesday 22/02/2022 between 10pm and 11:30pm. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea Village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and this alert may need to remain in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely Today, Tuesday 22nd February, and for at least the next 24hrs. We are continuing to see high water levels, but are expecting them to start dropping soon as storm conditions ease and spring tides move to neaps. The forecast tides at Gt Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Wednesday 23rd February.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 06:15 on 23/02/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 127 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake and river levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent heavy rainfall overnight. Further rain is forecast today, 22/02/2022 and we expect levels to remain above flood alert levels. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the lake frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site for a number of days. We are continuing to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near Derwentwater and local watercourses which may be flooded and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated on tomorrow morning, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high on Windermere and on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent heavy rainfall. Further rain is forecast today, 22/02/2022, and levels are expected to remain above flood alert levels. We do not expect flooding to properties. Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. We are continuing to monitor the forecast and re-issue alerts or warnings if necessary. We are clearing debris from screens and checking watercourses for blockages in the area and monitoring local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 23/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.message: A flood alert remains in force for the lower River Wharfe as a result of recent heavy rainfall. River levels in the Wharfe have peaked and we expect the river to remain high overnight and then fall slowly. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wharfe, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the lower River Wharfe and tributaries from Ilkley to upstream of Ullerskelf. We are monitoring river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold, consequently this flood alert is no longer in force.
Although further unsettled weather and showers are forecast, we are not expecting any further significant rainfall. Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from swollen watercourses and flood water and be aware of debris and surface water affecting roads. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will issue further flood alerts and warnings if required over the next few days.

Levels on the River Aire remain elevated at Kildwick, but have now fallen below the flood risk threshold, so this flood alert is no longer in force. Washlands at Snaygill Ings, Skipton and Cononley are beginning to drain steadily, but will still contain water for some time as this process takes place. River levels are expected to continue to fall steadily, and though some light rain is forecast over the next 48 hours, we do not anticipate this will cause additional flood risk. Please be aware that local washlands and low-lying land may contain floodwater for some time. 
For a 5 day flood forecast, please see the GOV.UK website.

River levels remain high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge. River levels remain high but are now falling slowly at the Llanymynech & Maesbrook river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre and the road from Maesbrook to Melverley may be flooded. 
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 5.3m on Sunday night, 20/02/22. The current level at the Cae Howel gauge is 6.03m and steady at 3pm on Tuesday 22/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5pm Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Llanymynech & Cae Howel river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Maesbrook.
 Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 5.3m on Sunday evening 20/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Llanymynech, Cae Howel and Crew Green river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Melverley including Melverley to Melverley Green and Ponthen to Melverley roads.
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 5.3m on Sunday 20/02/22. 
Crew Green peaked at 6.58m on Monday evening, 21/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: This Flood Warning has been removed as the River Ure at Westwick Weir and Boroughbridge has fallen below the level that would cause property flooding in this warning area. The River Ure had risen upstream in response to recent rainfall and is now falling, we do not expect this to have an impact on levels downstream. Further rainfall may see levels rise again but this is not expected to produce levels as high as we have seen over the last few days. We will continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. To report any property flooding, please call 0800 80 70 60.

Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. River levels remain high at the Hay on Wye, Bredwardine, Belmont, Old Wye Bridge, Mordiford & Ross on Wye river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye.
Other locations that may be affected include the main A438 between Letton & Willersey, Byford, Bredwardine, Hereford, the North River bank footpath Hereford & King Georges playing fields. Wilton lane may flood up to the Fishermans Reach junction, Ross.  
Peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 4.6m Monday morning 21/02/22, Bredwardine at 6.55m Monday morning 21/02/22, Belmont at 6.08m Monday evening 21/02/22, Old Wye Bridge at 5.38m on Monday evening 21/02/22 and Mordiford at 5.13m Monday evening 21/02/22.
Predicted peaks:-  Ross on Wye 4.6m to 4.75m on Tuesday afternoon 22/02/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the upper River Ouse remains in force as river levels remain high. The River Ouse has peaked at a level of 4.58m on Tuesday 22/02/22. The river levels are now beginning to fall slowly. Flooding continues to affect locations near the River Ouse and several flood warnings remain in force, with low lying land most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land in York, and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The Foss Barrier in York is operating, and our field teams have closed riverside floodgates. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and up to date river levels. This message will be updated on Wednesday afternoon 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at all river gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Flooding is affecting low lying land & roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Hayes Basin, White Abbey, Leighton, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge, Bridgnorth & Gravel Hill Lane, Shrewsbury.
Crew Green peaked at 6.58m & Montford peaked at 7.03m Monday evening 21/02/22; Welshbridge peaked at 5.15m Tuesday morning 22/02/22.
Predicted peaks: Buildwas 6.7 to 6.9m Tuesday night 22/02/22 & Bridgnorth 5.0 to 5.3m overnight on Tuesday 22/02/22.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our incident response staff are checking defences. The river level forecasts displayed on GOV.UK are the raw data output from the Forecasting System computer models. These have not had an expert Flood Forecaster adjustment applied. This will sometimes result in slightly different level forecasts between levels provided on GOV.UK and those shown in this message.
This message will be updated by 10am 23/02/22 or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are now returning to normal throughout the day.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the next few days.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

River levels remain high at the Willington and Shardlow river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today, 23/02/2022 and over the next few days. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated in 12 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to fall around Ferrybridge Lock, however they still remain high around Beal.
Water levels in the Washlands adjacent to the river have also started to fall but drainage of river water from these areas may take several days. Please take care when near the Washlands. Rainfall over the next few days is not forecast to be significant and so the river level will continue to fall through the week. Please see GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads including the A645 Branch Road around Snaith. Water levels in washlands adjacent to the river have also started to fall, but drainage of river water from these areas may take several days. Please take care when near the washlands. Rainfall over the next few days is not forecast to be significant and so the river level will continue to fall through the week. Please see GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 08:00am 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Ross-On-Wye and Lydbrook river gauges following heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  Flooding is affecting low lying land and roads along the River Wye.
Ross on Wye peaked at 4.71m on Tuesday morning, 22/02/22.   
We expect river levels to remain high for several days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 7pm on Wednesday 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall slowly at the Leintwardine, Onibury & Ludlow (Corve) river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. River levels are currently rising on the River Thame following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue this evening and overnight, 22/02/2022, especially around the Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. 

This evening and overnight, 22/02/2022, should be mainly dry. Scattered showers are then forecast tomorrow afternoon. Levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold in Aylesbury. Levels have stabilised at Thame and Stadhampton this afternoon but remain high, especially in the Thame area. Levels continue to rise at Dorchester as water makes its way downstream. We expect river levels to remain high and out of banks over the coming days. 

Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
High tides combined with high fluvial levels will be at their highest, Wednesday 23/02/22 between 1am and 3am. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks:-, 
Gloucester 3.7 to 4.1m and Sandhurst 4.0m to 4.4m on Friday 25/02/22;
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday, 23/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are Collingham, Sutton on Trent, North Clifton, Torksey, Lea, Church Laneham to Rampton Road, Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge. Tuesday the 22nd of February's afternoon tide at 14:45 is expected to be 0.5m lower than the tide at 02:15 Tuesday morning 22/02/2022. The tides will remain low and gradually fall for the rest of the week, as we head towards a series of neap tides. This will reduce the risk of flooding. Strong winds will continue until the weekend, but should only generate very small amounts of windblown spray. 

Our operations staff have moved shingle at Medmerry West Beach, to try and improve the beach crest there and further reduce flood risk. We will continue to monitor the beach and weather forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.message: The forecast is now improving and the risk of flooding has now passed. No significant rainfall is forecast in the near future.

River levels have now fallen, however Mickletown Ings remains full. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible today, Tuesday 22/02/2022. The area most at risk is Mill Lane. Mickletown Ings is reaching capacity, therefore there is a risk that nearby properties may flood. The water levels in the Ings will remain high throughout today (Tuesday 22/02/2022) but should begin to slowly drain over the next few days. Despite ongoing unsettled weather, we are not expecting any large rainfall amounts here, or higher up the catchment, over the next couple of days. We continue to closely monitor the situation. To report flooding, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. This message will be updated by 03:55, 23/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

Washland levels remain high at Chapel Haddlesey as the impacts from recent rain storms move down the Lower Aire catchment. This warning remains in force as the washlands, which have been very full here for the last 24 hours, remain at levels where we may see some overtopping. Due to this increase in risk, property flooding in locations closest to the washlands is possible today, 22/02/22. Although we expect levels in the washlands to remain high for some time, we do not expect severe increases in the levels and the weather outlook is not showing significant rainfall here, or higher up the catchment, over the next couple of days. We continue to closely monitor the situation. Please put your flood plan into action and take care when near washlands and low-lying land, which may be flooded. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.message: Heavy rain over the weekend has caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. River levels have risen on the Upper River Derwent following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight tonight, Wednesday 23/02/2022. River levels remain high, with no further significant rise forecast. Levels at West Holme Washlands rose throughout yesterday and today, 22/02/22, as a result of the persistent, heavy rainfall from Sunday, passing down the River Aire. Water levels are very high and at a level where there is a risk of property flooding to locations nearest the washlands throughout today. Though we expect levels in the washlands to remain high for some time, we do not expect significant increases in the levels. The weather outlook is not showing significant rainfall here, or higher up the catchment, over the next couple of days. We expect levels to begin falling later this evening and overnight, into tomorrow, 23/02/2022. We are continuing to closely monitor the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and please put your flood plan into action. This message will be updated by 01:10, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Levels on the River Don at Fishlake remain high due to the heavy rain this weekend that resulted in the washlands steadily filling. Water has stopped spilling into the Washlands as of this morning, 22/02/2022. This warning remains in force tonight as levels in the river still indicate a higher than normal flood risk, and the Washlands still contain a significant amount of water. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours and we expect the river levels to continue falling steadily. We are deploying additional pumps in the area tomorrow, 23/2/22, which will help to reduce Washland levels more quickly. Consequently we expect the flood risk to reduce and will keep the need for this warning under review. Our field teams remain in the area monitoring the situation and checking defences. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid driving through floodwater. This message will be updated by 05:05am, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge following last weekends storms. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over Tuesday night, 22/02/2022. This information is correct as of 16:45 on Tuesday 22 February. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 10 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 08:00 Wednesday, 23/02/22.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are rising on the River Cherwell as a result of rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is expected this evening and overnight, 22/02/2022, in the areas around Thrupp.

This evening and overnight, 22/02/2022, should be mainly dry. Scattered showers are then forecast tomorrow afternoon. Levels are gradually rising on the Lower River Cherwell. Levels are forecast to continue rising around Thrupp this evening. Levels should then stabilise and begin falling tomorrow morning. Levels will remain high over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/02/2022, or as the situation changes.
